For complete details on all available configuration settings, see the Settings documentation.

docs.title: Connection Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage data connections in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Connections provide secure access to external data sources and enable data integration across various platforms.

Resource Type

Type: .Connection

To explore all connection commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .Connection

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the connections collection using absolute path.

fab cd /.connections

Navigate to a specific connection using relative path.

fab cd ../.connections/conn1.Connection

docs.title: Create Basic SQL Connection
docs.text:
Create a connection to SQL database with required parameters only.

fab create .connections/conn.Connection -P connectionDetails.type=SQL,connectionDetails.parameters.server=<server>,connectionDetails.parameters.database=sales,credentialDetails.type=Basic,credentialDetails.username=<username>,credentialDetails.password=<password>

docs.title: Create Connection with Gateway
docs.text:
Create a connection that uses a specific gateway for secure access.

fab create .connections/conn.Connection -P gateway=MyVnetGateway.Gateway,connectionDetails.type=SQL,connectionDetails.parameters.server=<server>,connectionDetails.parameters.database=sales,credentialDetails.type=Basic,credentialDetails.username=<username>,credentialDetails.password=<password>

docs.title: Create Connection with All Parameters
docs.text:
Create a connection with comprehensive configuration including privacy level and encryption settings.

fab create .connections/conn.Connection -P privacyLevel=Private,connectionDetails.creationMethod=SQL,gatewayId=852aee7c-d056-48dc-891f-9d7110a01b88,connectionDetails.type=SQL,connectionDetails.parameters.server=<server>,connectionDetails.parameters.database=sales,credentialDetails.type=Basic,credentialDetails.username=<username>,credentialDetails.password=<password>,credentialDetails.connectionEncryption=NotEncrypted,credentialDetails.skipTestConnection=False

docs.title: Check Connection Existence
docs.text:
Check if a specific connection exists and is accessible.

fab exists .connections/conn1.Connection

docs.title: Get Connection Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full connection details.

fab get .connections/conn1.Connection

docs.title: Export Connection Details
docs.text:
Query and export connection properties to a local directory.

fab get .connections/conn1.Connection -q . -o /tmp

docs.title: List Connections
docs.text:
Display all available connections in simple format.

fab ls .connections

docs.title: List Connections with Details
docs.text:
Show connections with detailed information including connection type, parameters, and configuration.

fab ls .connections -l

docs.title: Change Privacy Level
docs.text:
Update the privacy level setting for a connection.

fab set .connections/conn.Connection -q privacyLevel -i Organizational

docs.title: Update Password
docs.text:
Change the authentication password for a connection.

fab set .connections/conn.Connection -q credentialDetails.password -i <new_password>

docs.title: Remove a connection with interactive confirmation
docs.text: fab rm .connections/sql-conn.Connection

docs.title: Remove a connection without confirmation prompts
docs.text: fab rm .connections/gateway-conn.Connection -f

docs.title: Get Connection Permissions
docs.text:
Retrieve full connection permission details.

fab acl get .connections/conn.Connection

docs.title: Query Connection Permission Principals
docs.text:
Extract principal information using JMESPath query.

fab acl get .connections/conn.Connection -q [*].principal

docs.title: Export Connection Permission Query
docs.text:
Save connection permission query results to a local directory.

fab acl get .connections/conn.Connection -q [*].principal -o /tmp

docs.title: Export to Lakehouse from Connection Context
docs.text:
Navigate to connection and export permissions to Lakehouse.

fab cd .connections/conn.Connection
fab acl get . -q [*].principal -o /ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files

docs.title: List Connection Permissions
docs.text:
Display permissions assigned to a connection.

fab acl ls .connections/conn.Connection

docs.title: List Detailed Connection Permissions
docs.text:
Show connection permissions with detailed information including roles and principal details.

fab acl ls .connections/conn.Connection -l

docs.title: Describe (desc) Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to use the desc command to explore and understand available commands for different Fabric resource types. The describe functionality helps you discover what operations are supported for specific items and elements.

To explore all describe commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc -h

docs.title: Fabric Items Elements
docs.text: Fabric items are the primary content types within workspaces, including notebooks, datasets, reports, and other analytical assets.

docs.title: Check Item Commands by Extension
docs.text:
Check available commands for item using the extension syntax.

fab desc .Notebook

docs.title: Check Item Commands by Existing Path
docs.text:
Check available commands for an existing item using its full path.

fab desc ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook

docs.title: Check Commands by Extension
docs.text:
Check available commands for virtual item using the extension syntax.

fab desc .Capacity

docs.title: Check Commands by Existing Path
docs.text:
Check available commands for an existing virtual item using its full path.

fab desc .capacities/capac1.Capacity

docs.title: Virtual Elements List
docs.text: The following non-item elements are available for description:

docs.title: Tenant-Level Resources
docs.text:
# Capacity management
fab desc .Capacity

# Data gateway management  
fab desc .Gateway

# Connection management
fab desc .Connection

# Domain management
fab desc .Domain

docs.title: Workspace-Level Resources
docs.text:
# Workspace management
fab desc .Workspace

# External data sharing
fab desc .ExternalDataShare

# Identity management
fab desc .ManagedIdentity

# Network endpoints
fab desc .ManagedPrivateEndpoint

# Spark compute resources
fab desc .SparkPool

The desc command is your gateway to understanding the full capabilities of Fabric CLI for any resource type. Use it liberally to explore and discover new functionality.

docs.title: Domain Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage domains in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Domains provide hierarchical organization and governance capabilities for workspaces and data assets within your Fabric tenant.

Resource Type

Type: .Domain

To explore all domain commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .Domain

Contributors Scope Options:

Scope Description Use Case AdminsOnly Only domain admins can contribute Restricted, governance-focused domains AllTenant All tenant users can contribute Open collaboration domains SpecificUsersAndGroups Selected users/groups only Controlled access domains

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the domains collection using absolute path:

fab cd .domains

Navigate to a specific domain using relative path:

fab cd ../.domains/finance.Domain

docs.title: Domain Management
docs.text: A domain can only have a parent if that parent domain has no parent itself. This creates a maximum two-level hierarchy

docs.title: Create a domain
docs.text: fab create .domains/marketing.Domain

docs.title: Create a domain with a parent domain for hierarchical organization
docs.text: fab create .domains/sales-americas.Domain -P parentDomainName=sales,description="Sales domain for Americas region"

docs.title: Create a child domain using full domain reference
docs.text: fab create .domains/sales-emea.Domain -P parentDomainName=sales.Domain

docs.title: Check if a specific domain exists and is accessible
docs.text: fab exists .domains/finance.Domain

docs.title: Get Domain Details
docs.text: fab get .domains/finance.Domain

docs.title: Get Domain using query and export properties to a local directory
docs.text: fab get .domains/finance.Domain -q . -o /tmp

docs.title: Display existing domains in a simple format.
docs.text: fab ls .domains

docs.title: Show domains with detailed information.
docs.text: fab ls .domains -l

docs.title: Update Domain
docs.text:
Domain property updates require Fabric admin role

Supported Properties:

  • contributorsScope: Who can contribute to the domain
  • description: Domain description
  • displayName: Domain display name

docs.title: Update the display name of a domain
docs.text: fab set .domains/finance.Domain -q displayName -i "accounting"

docs.title: Update who can contribute to the domain
docs.text: fab set .domains/finance.Domain -q contributorsScope -i "AdminsOnly"

docs.title: Remove a domain with interactive confirmation
docs.text: fab rm .domains/test-domain.Domain

docs.title: Remove a domain without confirmation prompts
docs.text: fab rm .domains/deprecated-domain.Domain -f

docs.title: Assign Domain To Workspace
docs.text: fab assign .domains/finance.Domain -W finance-workspace.Workspace

docs.title: Unassign Domain From Workspace
docs.text: fab unassign .domains/finance.Domain -W finance-workspace.Workspace

docs.title: External Data Share Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage external data shares in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI.

Resource Type

Type: .ExternalDataShare

To explore all external data share commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .ExternalDataShare

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the external data shares collection within a workspace:

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares

Navigate to a specific external data share:

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/eds1.ExternalDataShare

docs.title: Create External Data Shares
docs.text:
The 'External data sharing' tenant setting must be enabled by your Fabric administrator before creating external data shares

Required Parameters: item, paths, recipient.tenantId and recipient.userPrincipalName.

docs.title: Create Basic External Data Share
docs.text:
Create an external data share with required parameters to share specific paths with an external user.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/customer-data-share.ExternalDataShare -P item=analytics.Lakehouse,paths=[Files/public-data],recipient.tenantId=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000,recipient.userPrincipalName=fabcli@microsoft.com

docs.title: Create External Data Share with Multiple Paths
docs.text:
Share multiple directories or files with an external recipient.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/multi-path-share.ExternalDataShare -P item=research.Lakehouse,paths=[Files/reports,Files/datasets,Tables/public_metrics],recipient.tenantId=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000,recipient.userPrincipalName=fabcli@microsoft.com

docs.title: Create External Data Share for Warehouse
docs.text:
Share warehouse data with external partners.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/warehouse-share.ExternalDataShare -P item=sales.Warehouse,paths=[Tables/public_sales_data],recipient.tenantId=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000,recipient.userPrincipalName=fabcli@microsoft.com

docs.title: Check External Data Share Existence
docs.text:
Check if a specific external data share exists and is accessible.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/eds1.ExternalDataShare

docs.title: Get External Data Share Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full external data share details in JSON format.

fab get ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/eds1.ExternalDataShare -q .

docs.title: Export External Data Share Details
docs.text:
Query and export external data share properties to a local directory.

fab get ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/eds1.ExternalDataShare -q . -o /tmp

docs.title: List All External Data Shares
docs.text:
Display all external data shares in the workspace in simple format.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares

docs.title: List External Data Shares with Details
docs.text:
Show external data shares with detailed information including recipients, paths, and status.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares -l

docs.title: Remove External Data Share with Confirmation
docs.text:
Revoke an external data share with interactive confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/analytics.ExternalDataShare

docs.title: Force Remove External Data Share
docs.text:
Remove an external data share without confirmation prompts.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.externaldatashares/research.ExternalDataShare -f

docs.title: Folder Management Examples
docs.text:
Enable Folder Listing

By default, the ls command does not display folders. To enable folder listing, run the following command:

fab config set folder_listing_enabled true

This page demonstrates how to manage folders in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Folder operations allow you to organize items and resources within workspaces and supported item types.

Resource Type

Type: .Folder

To explore all folder-related commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .Folder

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to a folder using the full workspace path.

fab cd ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder

Navigate to a workspace using relative path from current context.

fab cd ../../ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder

docs.title: Create Folder
docs.text:
Create a new folder within a workspace.

fab create ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder

docs.title: Folder Existence
docs.text:
Check if a folder exists.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder

docs.title: Get Folder Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full folder details.

fab get ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder

docs.title: Query Specific Properties
docs.text:
Query folder properties using JMESPath syntax.

fab get ws1.Workspace/f1.Folder -q id

docs.title: Export Query Results
docs.text:
Save query results to a local file.

fab get ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder -q parentFolderId -o /tmp

docs.title: List Folders
docs.text:
List the workspace contents. This command returns both items and folders within the workspace. 

fab ls ws1.Workspace

docs.title: List Folder Items
docs.text:
List the contents of a folder. Use -l for detailed output.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder

docs.title: Update Folder
docs.text:
Set or update folder properties (currently only displayName is supported). Use -f to force updates.

fab set ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder -q displayName -i fd1ren

docs.title: Remove Folder
docs.text:
Remove a folder. Use -f to force deletion without confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/fd1.Folder

docs.title: Copy Folder to Workspace
docs.text:
The folder is copied to the root of the destination workspace, preserving its name. This will fail if a folder with the same name already exists.

fab cp source.Workspace/source.Folder target.Workspace

Result: target.Workspace/source.Folder

docs.title: Copy Folder to Folder
docs.text:
• If the destination folder exists, the source folder is copied inside it.

    fab cp ws.Workspace/source.Folder ws.Workspace/dest.Folder

    Result: ws.Workspace/dest.Folder/source.Folder

  • If the destination folder does not exist, the source folder is renamed to the destination folder name.

    fab cp ws.Workspace/source.Folder ws.Workspace/dest.Folder

    Result: ws.Workspace/dest.Folder

docs.title: Move Folder To Workspace
docs.text:
Move folder to workspace, preserving its name.

This command will fail if a folder with the same name already exists

fab mv ws1.Workspace/source.Folder ws2.Workspace

docs.title: Move Folder To Folder
docs.text:
• If the destination folder does not exist, the source folder is renamed to the destination folder name.

    fab mv ws1.Workspace/source.Folder ws2.Workspace/dest.Folder

    Result: ws2.Workspace/dest.Folder

  • If the destination folder exists, the source folder is moved inside it.

    fab mv ws1.Workspace/source.Folder ws2.Workspace/dest.Folder

    Result: ws2.Workspace/dest.Folder/source.Folder

For managing folders within OneLake storage (e.g., Lakehouse/Files), see OneLake Examples

docs.title: Gateway Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage on-premises and virtual network (VNet) data gateways in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI.

Resource Type

Type: .Gateway

To explore all gateway commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .Gateway

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the gateways collection using absolute path:

fab cd /.gateways

Navigate to a specific gateway using relative path:

fab cd ../.gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway

docs.title: Create Gateway
docs.text:
Create a gateway synchronously. Use optional parameters with -P as needed; defaults apply if unspecified — see config set.

VNet Gateway Prerequisites

Before creating a VNet Gateway, ensure all requirements are met:

  • Feature is supported in your region
  • Subnet follows all requirements and is properly delegated
  • Proper permissions on Azure subscription and VNet
  • See VNet Gateway Documentation for complete requirements

docs.title: Create Basic VNet Gateway
docs.text:
Create a VNet gateway with required parameters only.

fab create .gateways/basic-vnet-gateway.Gateway -P capacity=mycapacityname,virtualNetworkName=west-us-2-fabric-test-vnet,subnetName=vnet-gateway

docs.title: Create VNet Gateway with Custom Configuration
docs.text:
Create a VNet gateway with additional configuration parameters.

fab create .gateways/advanced-vnet-gateway.Gateway -P capacity=production-capacity,resourceGroupName=fabric-rg,subscriptionId=25bdf70e-a1b2-4c3d-8e9f-123456789abc,virtualNetworkName=prod-fabric-vnet,subnetName=prod-gateway-subnet,inactivityMinutesBeforeSleep=60,numberOfMemberGateways=2

docs.title: Check Gateway Existence
docs.text:
Check if a specific gateway exists and is accessible.

fab exists .gateways/prodgateway.Gateway

docs.title: Get Gateway Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full gateway details.

fab get .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway

docs.title: Export Gateway Details
docs.text:
Query and export gateway properties to a local directory.

fab get .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway -q . -o /tmp

docs.title: Display existing gateways in a simple format.
docs.text: fab ls .gateways

docs.title: Show gateways with detailed information.
docs.text: fab ls .gateways -l

docs.title: Update Gateway
docs.text:
Update the display name of a gateway for better identification.

fab set .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway -q displayName -i "Production Data Gateway"

docs.title: Remove Gateway
docs.text:
Gateway Deletion Impact

Removing a gateway will affect all connections and data sources that depend on it. Ensure dependent resources are updated or migrated before deletion.

docs.title: Remove a gateway with interactive confirmation
docs.text: fab rm .gateways/old-gateway.Gateway

docs.title: Remove a gateway without confirmation prompts.
docs.text: fab rm .gateways/test-gateway.Gateway -f

docs.title: Get Gateway Permission Details
docs.text: fab acl get .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway

docs.title: Query Gateway Permission Principals
docs.text:
Extract principal information using JMESPath query.

fab acl get .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway -q "[*].principal"

docs.title: Export Gateway Permission Query
docs.text:
Save gateway permission query results to a local directory.

fab acl get .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway -q "[*].principal" -o /tmp

docs.title: Export to Lakehouse from Gateway Context
docs.text:
Navigate to gateway and export permissions to Lakehouse.

fab cd .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway
fab acl get . -q "[*].principal" -o /ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files

docs.title: List Gateway Permissions
docs.text: fab acl ls .gateways/prod-gateway.Gateway

docs.title: Item Management Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage Microsoft Fabric items using the CLI. Items are the core resource types within Fabric workspaces, including notebooks, reports, lakehouses, etc.

Resource Types

Type: .<item_type> (e.g., .Notebook, .Lakehouse, .Report)

To explore commands for any item type, run:

fab desc .<item_type>

See all available item extensions.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to an item using its full path.

fab cd /ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse

Navigate to an item using relative path from current context.

fab cd ../ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse

docs.title: Create Item
docs.text:
Unsupported Items: .Dashboard, .Datamart, .MirroredWarehouse, .PaginatedReport, .SQLEndpoint

Items with Required Parameters:

  • .MountedDataFactory: subscriptionId, resourceGroup, factoryName

Items with Optional Parameters:

  • .Lakehouse: enableSchemas
  • .Warehouse: enableCaseInsensitive
  • .KQLDatabase: dbtype, eventhouseId, clusterUri, databaseName
  • .MirroredDatabase: mirrorType, connectionId, defaultSchema, database, mountedTables
  • .Report: semanticModelId

docs.title: Create Basic Items
docs.text:
Create items without special parameters.

fab create ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse

docs.title: Create Items with Parameters
docs.text:
Create items with specific configuration parameters.

fab create ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -P enableSchemas=true

docs.title: Check Item Supported Parameters
docs.text:
View supported parameters for any item type.

fab create lh1.Lakehouse -P

docs.title: Check Item Existence
docs.text:
Check if a specific item exists and is accessible.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook

docs.title: Get Item
docs.text:
When you get an item definition, the sensitivity label is not a part of the definition

Unsupported Items: .Dashboard, .Datamart, .MirroredWarehouse, .PaginatedReport, .SQLEndpoint

docs.title: Get Item Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full item details.

fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse

docs.title: Get All Properties (Verbose)
docs.text:
Show comprehensive item properties including extended metadata.

fab get ws1.Workspace/rep1.Report -v

docs.title: Query Specific Properties
docs.text:
Extract specific properties using JMESPath query.

fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -q properties.sqlEndpointProperties

docs.title: Export Query Results
docs.text:
Save query results to a local directory.

fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -q properties.sqlEndpointProperties -o /tmp

docs.title: List Items in Workspace
docs.text:
Display all items within a workspace.

fab ls ws1.Workspace

docs.title: List Items with Details
docs.text:
Show items with comprehensive metadata.

fab ls ws1.Workspace -l

docs.title: List Item Contents
docs.text:
Browse contents of items that support folder structures.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse
fab ls ws1.Workspace/wh1.Warehouse
fab ls ws1.Workspace/sem1.SemanticModel

Items Supporting OneLake Folder Structure:

  • .Lakehouse
  • .Warehouse
  • .MirroredDatabase
  • .SQLDatabase
  • .SemanticModel1
  • .KQLDatabase1

docs.title: Update Display Name
docs.text:
Change the display name of an item.

fab set ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -q displayName -i "Updated Notebook Name"

docs.title: Set Description
docs.text:
Add or update item description.

fab set ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -q description -i "Production data lakehouse"

docs.title: Remove Item with Confirmation
docs.text:
Delete an item with interactive confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook

docs.title: Force Remove Item
docs.text:
Delete an item without confirmation prompts.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -f

docs.title: Update Item Properties
docs.text:
Configurable Properties by Item Type:

  • All supported items: displayName, description
  • Notebook: lakehouse, environment, warehouse
  • Report: semanticModelId
  • SparkJobDefinition: payload

docs.title: Set default lakehouse, environment, or warehouse for a notebook.
docs.text:
# Set default lakehouse
fab set ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -q lakehouse -i '{"known_lakehouses": [{"id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001"}],"default_lakehouse": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001", "default_lakehouse_name": "lh1","default_lakehouse_workspace_id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000"}'

# Set default environment
fab set ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -q environment -i '{"environmentId": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000002", "workspaceId": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000"}'

# Set default warehouse
fab set ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -q warehouse -i '{"known_warehouses": [{"id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000003", "type": "Datawarehouse"}], "default_warehouse": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000003"}'

docs.title: Rebind Report to Semantic Model
docs.text: fab set ws1.Workspace/rep1.Report -q semanticModelId -i "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000

docs.title: Copy Items
docs.text:
When you copy an item definition, the sensitivity label is not a part of the definition

Supported Item Types for Copy:

  • .Notebook, .SparkJobDefinition, .DataPipeline
  • .Report, .SemanticModel
  • .KQLDatabase, .KQLDashboard, .KQLQueryset
  • .Eventhouse, .Eventstream
  • .MirroredDatabase, .Reflex
  • .MountedDataFactory, .CopyJob, .VariableLibrary

docs.title: Copy Item to Workspace
docs.text:
Copy an item to the a workspace, preserving its original name.

fab cp ws1.Workspace/source.Item target.Workspace

docs.title: Copy Item With to Workspace with a new Item Name
docs.text:
Copy an item to the destination and rename.

fab cp ws1.Workspace/source.Item ws2.Workspace/dest.Item

docs.title: Copy Item to Folder
docs.text:
Copy an item into the destination folder. If the folder does not exist, it will be created.

fab cp ws1.Workspace/source.Item ws2.Workspace/dest.Folder

docs.title: Move Items
docs.text: When you move item definition, the sensitivity label is not a part of the definition

docs.title: Move Item to Workspace
docs.text:
Move an item to a workspace (removes from source).

fab mv ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook ws2.Workspace

docs.title: Move Item To Workspace with a New Name
docs.text:
Move an item to the destination and rename.

fab mv ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook ws2.Workspace/nb_new_name.Notebook

docs.title: Move Item To Folder
docs.text:
Move an item into a folder, preserving its original name.

fab mv ws1.Workspace/nb.Notebook ws2.Workspace/dest.Folder

docs.title: Import and Export
docs.text: When you export item definition, the sensitivity label is not a part of the definition

docs.title: Export to Local
docs.text:
Export an item definition to a local directory.

fab export ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -o /tmp

Exportable Item Types:

  • .Notebook, .SparkJobDefinition, .DataPipeline
  • .Report, .SemanticModel
  • .KQLDatabase, .KQLDashboard, .KQLQueryset
  • .Eventhouse, .Eventstream, .MirroredDatabase
  • .Reflex, .MountedDataFactory, .CopyJob, .VariableLibrary

docs.title: Export to Lakehouse
docs.text:
Export item definition directly to a Lakehouse Files location.

fab export ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -o /ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/exports

docs.title: Import from Local
docs.text:
Import an item definition from a local directory into the workspace.

fab import ws1.Workspace/nb1_imported.Notebook -i /tmp/exports/nb1.Notebook

Import a notebook from Python file format instead of default format.

fab import ws1.Workspace/nb1_python.Notebook -i /tmp/notebook.py --format py

Supported Import Formats: .ipynb (default) and .py.

docs.title: Start Mirrored Database
docs.text:
Start data synchronization for a mirrored database.

fab start ws1.Workspace/mir1.MirroredDatabase

docs.title: Force Start Mirrored Database
docs.text:
Start mirrored database without confirmation.

fab start ws1.Workspace/mir1.MirroredDatabase -f

docs.title: Stop Mirrored Database
docs.text:
Stop data synchronization for a mirrored database.

fab stop ws1.Workspace/mir1.MirroredDatabase

docs.title: Force Stop Mirrored Database
docs.text:
Stop mirrored database without confirmation.

fab stop ws1.Workspacemir1.MirroredDatabase -f

docs.title: Open Item in Web Interface
docs.text:
Launch an item in the default web browser.

fab open ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse

  1. Requires explicit enablement ↩↩

docs.title: Job Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to run, monitor, and schedule jobs in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Jobs enable automation of notebooks, data pipelines, Spark job definitions, and table maintenance operations.

To explore all job commands and their parameters, run:

fab job -h

docs.title: Run Job and Wait for Completion
docs.text:
Execute a job synchronously, waiting for it to complete before returning control.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline

docs.title: Run Job with Timeout
docs.text:
Execute a job with a specific timeout limit in seconds.

# Run with 120 second timeout (job cancelled when timeout reached)
fab job run ws1.Workspace/sjd1.SparkJobDefinition --timeout 120

docs.title: Run Job with Timeout (No Cancellation)
docs.text:
Configure the CLI to continue jobs even after timeout.

# Configure to not cancel jobs on timeout
fab config set job_cancel_ontimeout false

# Job will continue running even after timeout
fab job run ws1.Workspace/sjd1.SparkJobDefinition --timeout 120

docs.title: Start Job Without Waiting
docs.text:
Launch a job asynchronously and return immediately without waiting for completion.

fab job start ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline

docs.title: Jobs with Parameters
docs.text:
Run .Notebook or .DataPipeline jobs using parameters -P.

Supported P Parameter Types:

  • .Notebook: string, int, float, bool
  • .DataPipeline: string, int, float, bool, object, array, secureString

docs.title: Run Notebook with Parameters
docs.text:
Execute a notebook job with custom parameters of different types.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -P string_param:string=new_value,int_param:int=10,float_param:float=0.1234,bool_param:bool=true

docs.title: Run Data Pipeline with Basic Parameters
docs.text:
Execute a pipeline with standard parameter types.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline -P string_param:string=new_value,int_param:int=10,float_param:float=0.1234,bool_param:bool=true

docs.title: Run Pipeline with Complex Parameters
docs.text:
Execute a pipeline with object, array, and secure string parameters.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline -P 'obj_param:object={"key":{"nested_key":2},"simple_key":"value"},array_param:array=[1,2,3],secstr_param:secureString=secret'

docs.title: Cancel Running Job
docs.text:
Stop a currently running job instance.

fab job run-cancel ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook --id <schedule_id>

docs.title: List Jobs
docs.text:
Supported Items:

  • .Notebook, .DataPipeline, .SparkJobDefinition, .Lakehouse

docs.title: List Job Execution History
docs.text:
Display all job runs for a specific item.

fab job run-list ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook

docs.title: List Scheduled Job Runs
docs.text:
Display job runs that were triggered by schedules.

fab job run-list ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook --schedule

docs.title: Check Job Instance Status
docs.text:
Get detailed status information for a specific job run.

fab job run-status ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook --id <schedule_id>

docs.title: Check Scheduled Job Status
docs.text:
Get status information for a scheduled job.

fab job run-status ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook --id <schedule_id> --schedule

docs.title: Create Cron-based Schedule
docs.text:
Schedule a job to run every 10 minutes with cron scheduling.

fab job run-sch ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --type cron --interval 10 --start 2024-11-15T09:00:00 --end 2024-12-15T10:00:00 --enable

docs.title: Create Daily Schedule
docs.text:
Schedule a job to run daily at specific times.

fab job run-sch ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --type daily --interval 10:00,16:00 --start 2024-11-15T09:00:00 --end 2024-12-16T10:00:00

docs.title: Create Weekly Schedule
docs.text:
Schedule a job to run on specific days of the week at designated times.

fab job run-sch ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --type weekly --interval 10:00,16:00 --days Monday,Friday --start 2024-11-15T09:00:00 --end 2024-12-16T10:00:00

docs.title: Create Schedule with Custom Configuration
docs.text:
Schedule a job using raw JSON configuration for advanced settings.

fab job run-sch ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline -i '{"enabled": true, "configuration": {"startDateTime": "2024-04-28T00:00:00", "endDateTime": "2024-04-30T23:59:00", "localTimeZoneId": "Central Standard Time", "type": "Cron", "interval": 10}}'

docs.title: Disable Job Schedule
docs.text:
Turn off a scheduled job without deleting the schedule.

fab job run-update ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --id <schedule_id> --disable

docs.title: Update Schedule Frequency
docs.text:
Modify an existing schedule to run every 10 minutes and enable it.

fab job run-update ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --id <schedule_id> --type cron --interval 10 --start 2024-11-15T09:00:00 --end 2024-12-15T10:00:00 --enable

docs.title: Update Daily Schedule Times
docs.text:
Change the execution times for a daily schedule.

fab job run-update ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --id <schedule_id> --type daily --interval 10:00,16:00 --start 2024-11-15T09:00:00 --end 2024-12-16T10:00:00

docs.title: Update Weekly Schedule
docs.text:
Modify a weekly schedule with new days and times.

fab job run-update ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --id <schedule_id> --type weekly --interval 10:00,16:00 --days Monday,Friday --start 2024-11-15T09:00:00 --end 2024-12-16T10:00:00 --enable

docs.title: Update Schedule with Custom Configuration
docs.text:
Update a schedule using raw JSON for complex configurations.

fab job run-update ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --id <schedule_id> -i '{"enabled": true, "configuration": {"startDateTime": "2024-04-28T00:00:00", "endDateTime": "2024-04-30T23:59:00", "localTimeZoneId": "Central Standard Time", "type": "Cron", "interval": 10}}'

docs.title: List All Scheduled Jobs
docs.text:
View all scheduled job runs and their status.

fab job run-list ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook --schedule

docs.title: Check Schedule Status
docs.text:
Get detailed information about a specific job schedule.

fab job run-status ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook --id <schedule_id> --schedule

docs.title: Permanently Disable Schedule
docs.text:
Disable a job schedule to prevent future executions.

fab job run-update ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline --id <schedule_id> --disable

docs.title: Run Notebook with Configuration File
docs.text:
Execute a notebook with configuration loaded from a JSON file.

fab job start ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -C ./config_file.json

docs.title: Run Notebook with Inline Configuration
docs.text:
Execute a notebook with inline JSON configuration for Spark settings.

fab job start ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -C '{"conf":{"spark.conf1": "value"}, "environment": {"id": "<environment_id>", "name": "<environment_name>"}}'

docs.title: Run Notebook with Default Lakehouse
docs.text:
Execute a notebook with a specified default lakehouse configuration.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -C '{"defaultLakehouse": {"name": "<lakehouse-name>", "id": "<lakehouse-id>", "workspaceId": "<(optional) workspace-id-that-contains-the-lakehouse>"}}'

docs.title: Run Notebook with Workspace Pool
docs.text:
Execute a notebook using a specific workspace Spark pool.

fab job start ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -C '{"defaultLakehouse": {"name": "<lakehouse-name>", "id": "<lakehouse-id>"}, "useStarterPool": false, "useWorkspacePool": "<workspace-pool-name>"}'

docs.title: Run Notebook with Configuration and Parameters
docs.text:
Combine configuration and parameters in a single job execution.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -P string_param:string=new_value -C '{"environment": {"id": "<environment_id>", "name": "<environment_name>"}}'

docs.title: Run Notebook with Raw JSON Input
docs.text:
Execute a notebook using raw JSON payload for complete control.

# Inline JSON
fab job run ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -i '{"parameters": {"string_param": {"type": "string", "value": "new_value"}}, "configuration": {"conf":{"spark.conf1": "value"}}}'

# From file
fab job run ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -i ./input_file.json

See notebook run payload options for complete configuration parameters.

docs.title: Run Pipeline with Raw JSON Parameters
docs.text:
Execute a pipeline using raw JSON input for parameters.

# Asynchronous with basic parameters
fab job start ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline -i '{"parameters": {"string_param": "new_value", "int_param": 10}}'

# Synchronous with complex parameters
fab job run ws1.Workspace/pip1.DataPipeline -i '{"parameters": {"float_param": 0.1234, "bool_param": true, "obj_param": {"key": "value"}, "array_param": [1, 2, 3], "secstr_param": "secret"}}'

See pipeline run payload options for complete configuration parameters.

docs.title: Run Basic Spark Job
docs.text:
Execute a Spark job definition without additional configuration.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/sjd1.SparkJobDefinition

docs.title: Run Spark Job with Payload Configuration
docs.text:
Execute a Spark job with specific environment and lakehouse settings.

fab job start ws1.Workspace/sjd1.SparkJobDefinition -i '{"commandLineArguments": "param01 TEST param02 1234", "environmentArtifactId": "<environment-id>", "defaultLakehouseArtifactId": "<lakehouse-id>", "additionalLakehouseIds": ["<lakehouse-id>"]}'

docs.title: Table Maintenance Jobs
docs.text: For easier table maintenance operations, see Table Management Examples for user-friendly commands

docs.title: Run Complete Table Optimization
docs.text:
Execute V-Order, Z-Order, and Vacuum operations on a table.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -i '{"tableName": "orders", "optimizeSettings": {"vOrder": true, "zOrderBy": ["account_id"]}, "vacuumSettings": {"retentionPeriod": "7.01:00:00"}}'

docs.title: Run Table Optimization Only
docs.text:
Execute V-Order and Z-Order operations without vacuum.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -i '{"tableName": "orders", "optimizeSettings": {"vOrder": true, "zOrderBy": ["account_id"]}}'

docs.title: Run Vacuum Operation Only
docs.text:
Execute only vacuum operation to clean up old files.

fab job run ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse -i '{"tableName": "orders", "vacuumSettings": {"retentionPeriod": "7.01:00:00"}}'

docs.title: Label Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage sensitivity labels in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Sensitivity labels help classify and protect data based on organizational policies and compliance requirements.

To explore all label commands and their parameters, run:

fab label -h

docs.title: Label Configuration
docs.text:
To use labels seamlessly, the CLI needs a local labels.json file mapping label IDs to names. Create a JSON file with your organization's sensitivity labels.

Labels configuration file example:

{
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Public",
            "id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001"
        },
        {
            "name": "Internal",
            "id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000002"
        },
        {
            "name": "Confidential",
            "id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000003"
        },
        {
            "name": "Highly Confidential",
            "id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000004"
        },
        {
            "name": "Restricted",
            "id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000005"
        }
    ]
}

docs.title: Configure CLI to Use Label Definitions
docs.text:
Set the CLI configuration to point to your local labels definition file.

fab config set local_definition_labels /tmp/labels.json

docs.title: List Local Labels
docs.text:
View all locally configured sensitivity labels and their mappings.

fab label list-local

docs.title: Set Label by Name
docs.text:
Apply a sensitivity label to an item using the label name.

fab label set ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook -n Confidential

docs.title: Force Apply Label
docs.text:
Apply a sensitivity label without confirmation prompts.

fab label set ws1.Workspace/dataset.Lakehouse -n "Highly Confidential" -f

docs.title: Remove Label with Confirmation
docs.text:
Remove a sensitivity label from an item with interactive confirmation.

fab label rm ws1.Workspace/nb1.Notebook

docs.title: Force Remove Label
docs.text:
Remove a sensitivity label without confirmation prompts.

fab label rm ws1.Workspace/temporary-data.Lakehouse -f

docs.title: Managed Identity Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage workspace-scoped managed identities in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Managed identities provide secure authentication for Fabric workspaces when accessing external Azure resources.

Resource Type

Type: .ManagedIdentity

To explore all managed identity commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .ManagedIdentity

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the managed identities collection within a workspace:

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities

Navigate to a specific managed identity using relative path:

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities/ws1.ManagedIdentity

docs.title: Create Managed Identity
docs.text:
Info

  • Only one managed identity per workspace is allowed
  • The managed identity name will be automatically set to the workspace name
  • Any provided name in the command is ignored
  • Attempting to create multiple identities triggers a WorkspaceIdentityAlreadyExists error

Create a managed identity for the workspace to enable secure access to Azure resources.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities/workspace-identity.ManagedIdentity

docs.title: Check Managed Identity Existence
docs.text:
Check if a managed identity exists for the workspace.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities/ws1.ManagedIdentity

docs.title: List All Managed Identities
docs.text:
Display all managed identities in the workspace in simple format.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities

docs.title: List Managed Identities with Details
docs.text:
Show managed identities with detailed information including configuration and status.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities -l

docs.title: Remove Managed Identity with Confirmation
docs.text:
Delete the workspace managed identity with interactive confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities/ws1.ManagedIdentity

docs.title: Force Remove Managed Identity
docs.text:
Delete the workspace managed identity without confirmation prompts.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.managedidentities/ws1.ManagedIdentity -f

docs.title: Managed Private Endpoint Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage private endpoints in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Managed private endpoints provide secure, private connectivity to Azure resources without exposing traffic to the public internet.

Resource Type

Type: .ManagedPrivateEndpoint

To explore all managed private endpoint commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .ManagedPrivateEndpoint

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the managed private endpoints collection within a workspace:

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints

Navigate to a specific managed private endpoint:

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/storage-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint

docs.title: Create Managed Private Endpoint
docs.text:
Required Parameters: targetPrivateLinkResourceId and targetSubresourceType.

Optional Parameters: autoApproveEnabled (default: false).

See Microsoft documentation for supported endpoints, resource ID formats, and subresource types

docs.title: Create Managed Private Endpoint to Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2
docs.text:
Create a private endpoint to securely connect to Azure Data Lake Storage.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/adls-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint -P targetPrivateLinkResourceId=/subscriptions/<subscription_id>/resourceGroups/<resource_group_name>/providers/Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/<storage_account_name>,targetsubresourcetype=dfs

docs.title: Create Auto-Approved Managed Private Endpoint to SQL Server
docs.text:
Create a private endpoint to SQL Server with automatic approval enabled.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/sql-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint -P targetPrivateLinkResourceId=/subscriptions/<subscription_id>/resourceGroups/<resource_group_name>/providers/Microsoft.Sql/servers/<sql_server_name>,targetSubresourceType=sqlServer,autoApproveEnabled=true

docs.title: Check Managed Private Endpoint Existence
docs.text:
Check if a specific managed private endpoint exists and is accessible.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/storage-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint

docs.title: Get Managed Private Endpoint Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full managed private endpoint details.

fab get ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/storage-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint

docs.title: Export Managed Private Endpoint Details
docs.text:
Query and export managed private endpoint properties to a local directory.

fab get ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/storage-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint -q . -o /tmp

docs.title: List All Managed Private Endpoints
docs.text:
Display all managed private endpoints in the workspace in simple format.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints

docs.title: List Managed Private Endpoints with Details
docs.text:
Show managed private endpoints with detailed information including target resources, status, and configuration.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints -l

docs.title: Remove Managed Private Endpoints
docs.text: Managed private endpoints cannot be removed while in Provisioning state. Wait for provisioning to complete before attempting removal

docs.title: Remove Managed Private Endpoint with Confirmation
docs.text:
Delete a managed private endpoint with interactive confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/deprecated-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint

docs.title: Force Remove Managed Private Endpoint
docs.text:
Delete a managed private endpoint without confirmation prompts.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.managedprivateendpoints/test-endpoint.ManagedPrivateEndpoint -f

docs.title: OneLake Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage files and folders in Microsoft Fabric OneLake using the CLI. OneLake provides unified data lake storage that's integrated across all Fabric experiences.

OneLake is the built-in data lake for Microsoft Fabric that provides a single, unified namespace for all your data. You can manage files and folders directly through the CLI for supported item types.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the Files section of a Lakehouse.

fab cd ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files

Navigate to the Tables section of a Lakehouse.

fab cd ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables

Navigate to a nested folder within the Files section.

fab cd ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/raw-data/2024

docs.title: Check Folder Existence
docs.text:
Check if a specific directory exists in OneLake.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/data-processing

docs.title: Check File Exists
docs.text:
Check if a specific file exists in OneLake.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/datasets/sales.parquet

docs.title: Get File/Folder Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full metadata for a file or folder.

fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/datasets

docs.title: Query Specific Properties
docs.text:
Extract specific properties using JMESPath queries.

# Get first path item
fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/datasets -q paths[0]

# Get complete object
fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/datasets -q .

docs.title: Export Metadata
docs.text:
Save metadata query results to local storage or OneLake.

# Export to local directory
fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/datasets -q paths[0] -o /tmp/metadata

docs.title: List OneLake Content
docs.text:
Items Supporting OneLake Folder Structure:

  • .Lakehouse
  • .Warehouse
  • .MirroredDatabase
  • .SQLDatabase
  • .SemanticModel1
  • .KQLDatabase1

Display content for an item.

# List Files section in Lakehouse
fab ls ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files

# List dbo Tables section in Warehouse
fab ls ws1.Workspace/wh1.Warehouse/Tables/dbo

# List Tables in SemanticModel
fab ls ws1.Workspace/sem1.SemanticModel/Tables

docs.title: Create Folders
docs.text: Create a folder in OneLake. Only supported for Files in .Lakehouse, Main and Libs folders in .SparkJobDefinition

docs.title: Create Directory in Lakehouse Files
docs.text:
Create a new folder within the Files section of a Lakehouse.

fab create ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/data-processing

docs.title: Create Nested Directories
docs.text:
Create folder structures for organizing data.

fab create ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/raw-data/2024/january
fab create ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/processed-data/reports

docs.title: Remove Folder
docs.text:
Delete a folder and its contents from OneLake.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/old-data

docs.title: Remove Specific File
docs.text:
Delete a specific file with force flag to skip confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/temp/temporary-file.csv -f

docs.title: Remove with Confirmation
docs.text:
Delete resources with interactive confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/important-folder

docs.title: Copy File with Same Name
docs.text:
Copy a file from one OneLake folder to another, maintaining the original filename.

fab cp ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/csv/data.csv ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/dest/

docs.title: Copy File with New Name
docs.text:
Copy a file to a different folder and rename it in the process.

fab cp ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/csv/data.csv ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/dest/renamed_data.csv

docs.title: Upload File with Same Name
docs.text:
Copy a local file to OneLake, keeping the original filename.

fab cp /tmp/local-data/dataset.csv ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/upload/

docs.title: Upload File with New Name
docs.text:
Upload a local file to OneLake and rename it during the upload process.

fab cp /tmp/local-data/dataset.csv ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/upload/processed_dataset.csv

docs.title: Download File with Same Name
docs.text:
Download a file from OneLake to a local directory, maintaining the filename.

fab cp ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/csv/fab.csv /tmp/mydir

docs.title: Download File with New Name
docs.text:
Download a file from OneLake and rename it locally.

fab cp ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/csv/fab.csv /tmp/mydir/renamed_copy_fab.csv

  1. Requires explicit enablement ↩↩

docs.title: Shortcut Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage shortcuts in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Shortcuts provide virtual access to data stored in external locations or other OneLake items without copying the data.

Shortcuts enable you to virtualize data from various sources including OneLake, Azure Data Lake Storage, Amazon S3, and other cloud storage services directly within your Lakehouse.

docs.title: Create Shortcut
docs.text: Create shortcuts in Lakehouse /Files or /Tables sections.

docs.title: Create an Internal OneLake File Shortcut
docs.text:
Create a shortcut to another OneLake Files location within the same tenant.

fab ln ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/shared_data.Shortcut --type oneLake --target ../../shared.Workspace/source.Lakehouse/Files/datasets

docs.title: Create an External Azure Data Lake Gen2 Shortcut
docs.text:
Create a shortcut to Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 for external data access.

fab ln ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/external_sales.Shortcut --type adlsGen2 -i '{"location": "https://<storage_name>.dfs.core.windows.net/", "subpath": "sales-data/2024", "connectionId": "<connection-id>"}'

docs.title: Verify File Shortcut Exists
docs.text:
Check if a shortcut exists in the Files section of a Lakehouse.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/external_data.Shortcut

docs.title: Verify Table Shortcut Exists
docs.text:
Check if a shortcut exists in the Tables section of a Lakehouse.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/external_table.Shortcut

docs.title: Get Shortcut Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full shortcut details including target information and configuration.

fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/external_data.Shortcut
fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/external_table.Shortcut

docs.title: Query Shortcut Target
docs.text:
Extract target information using JMESPath query.

fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/external_data.Shortcut -q target

docs.title: Get Complete Shortcut Object
docs.text:
Retrieve all shortcut properties for detailed analysis.

fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/external_table.Shortcut -q .

docs.title: Export Shortcut Details
docs.text:
Save shortcut configuration to local directory or OneLake.

# Export to local directory
fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/external_data.Shortcut -q target -o /tmp

# Export complete configuration
fab get ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/external_table.Shortcut -q . -o /tmp

docs.title: Rename File Shortcut
docs.text:
Change the name of a shortcut in the Files section.

fab set ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/updated_name.Shortcut -q name -i external_data

docs.title: Force Rename Table Shortcut
docs.text:
Rename a table shortcut without confirmation prompts.

fab set ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/customer_data.Shortcut -q name -i customer_master_data -f

docs.title: Remove File Shortcut
docs.text:
Delete a shortcut from the Files section with confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/old_external_data.Shortcut

docs.title: Force Remove Table Shortcut
docs.text:
Delete a shortcut from the Tables section without confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/deprecated_source.Shortcut -f

docs.title: Spark Pool Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage Spark pools in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Spark pools provide dedicated compute resources for data engineering and analytics workloads within workspaces.

Resource Type

Type: .SparkPool

To explore all Spark pool commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .SparkPool

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to the Spark pools collection within a workspace.

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools

Navigate to a specific Spark pool.

fab cd ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/analytics-pool.SparkPool

docs.title: Create Spark Pool
docs.text: Optional Parameters: nodeSize (default: Small), autoScale.maxNodeCount (default: 1) and autoScale.minNodeCount (default: 1). maxNodeCount must be greater or equal to minNodeCount.

docs.title: Create Basic Spark Pool
docs.text:
Create a Spark pool with default configuration (Small, single-node).

fab create ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/basic-pool.SparkPool

docs.title: Create Spark Pool with Custom Node Size
docs.text:
Create a Spark pool with a specific node size for different workload requirements.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/large-pool.SparkPool -P nodeSize=Large

docs.title: Create Auto-Scaling Spark Pool
docs.text:
Create a Spark pool with auto-scaling configuration for dynamic workloads.

fab create ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/scaling-pool.SparkPool -P nodeSize=Medium,autoScale.minNodeCount=1,autoScale.maxNodeCount=5

docs.title: Check Spark Pool Existence
docs.text:
Check if a specific Spark pool exists and is accessible.

fab exists ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/analytics-pool.SparkPool

docs.title: Get Spark Pool Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full Spark pool details.

fab get ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/analytics-pool.SparkPool

docs.title: Export Spark Pool Details
docs.text:
Query and export Spark pool properties to a local directory.

fab get ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/analytics-pool.SparkPool -q . -o /tmp

docs.title: List All Spark Pools
docs.text:
Display all Spark pools in the workspace in simple format.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools

docs.title: List Spark Pools with Details
docs.text:
Show Spark pools with detailed information including node configuration, scaling settings, and status.

fab ls ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools -l

docs.title: Update Spark Pool
docs.text: Supported Properties: name, nodeSize, autoScale.enabled, autoScale.minNodeCount and autoScale.maxNodeCount.

docs.title: Rename Spark Pool
docs.text:
Update the name of a Spark pool for better identification.

fab set ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/analytics-pool.SparkPool -q name -i "production-analytics-pool"

docs.title: Change Node Size
docs.text:
Update the node size to scale compute capacity up or down.

fab set ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/production-analytics-pool.SparkPool -q nodeSize -i Large

docs.title: Enable Auto-Scaling
docs.text:
Enable auto-scaling for dynamic resource allocation.

fab set ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/production-analytics-pool.SparkPool -q autoScale.enabled -i True

docs.title: Update Scaling Configuration
docs.text:
Modify minimum and maximum node counts for auto-scaling.

# Set maximum nodes
fab set ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/production-analytics-pool.SparkPool -q autoScale.maxNodeCount -i 8

# Set minimum nodes
fab set ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/production-analytics-pool.SparkPool -q autoScale.minNodeCount -i 2

docs.title: Remove Spark Pool with Confirmation
docs.text:
Delete a Spark pool with interactive confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/test-pool.SparkPool

docs.title: Force Remove Spark Pool
docs.text:
Delete a Spark pool without confirmation prompts.

fab rm ws1.Workspace/.sparkpools/deprecated-pool.SparkPool -f

docs.title: Table Management Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage tables in Microsoft Fabric using the CLI. Table operations enable schema inspection, data loading, optimization, and maintenance across various Fabric item types.

To explore all table commands and their parameters, run:

fab table -h

docs.title: Check Delta Table Schema
docs.text:
Items Supporting OneLake Schema:

  • .Lakehouse
  • .Warehouse
  • .MirroredDatabase
  • .SQLDatabase
  • .SemanticModel1
  • .KQLDatabase1

View the complete schema structure of a Delta table in a Lakehouse.

fab table schema ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/dbo/customer_data

docs.title: Data Loading
docs.text: Not supported in schema-enabled Lakehouses

docs.title: Load from Folder
docs.text:
Load all CSV files from a folder into a Delta table.

fab table load ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/customer_data --file ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/csv/customers

docs.title: Load Specific File with Append Mode
docs.text:
Load a specific CSV file and append to existing table data.

fab table load ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/sales_data --file ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/csv/daily_sales.csv --mode append

docs.title: Load CSV with Custom Format Options
docs.text:
Load CSV data with specific delimiter and header configuration.

fab table load ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/product_catalog --file ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/custom_csv --format format=csv,header=false,delimiter=';'

docs.title: Load Parquet Files
docs.text:
Load Parquet files into a Delta table with append mode.

fab table load ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/analytics_data --file ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/parquet/events --format format=parquet --mode append

docs.title: Load with File Extension Filter
docs.text:
Load only specific Parquet files using extension filtering.

fab table load ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/processed_data --file ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files/parquet/processed --format format=parquet --extension '.parquet'

docs.title: Table Optimization
docs.text: Supported only in Lakehouse

docs.title: Basic Table Optimization
docs.text:
Perform basic Delta table optimization to improve query performance.

fab table optimize ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/sales_data

docs.title: Optimize with V-Order and Z-Order
docs.text:
Run comprehensive optimization with both V-Order and Z-Order for maximum performance.

fab table optimize ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/customer_transactions --vorder --zorder customer_id,transaction_date

docs.title: Vacuum Operations
docs.text: Supported only in Lakehouse

docs.title: Default Vacuum Operation
docs.text:
Remove old files using the default retention period (7 days).

fab table vacuum ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/transaction_history

docs.title: Vacuum with Custom Retention
docs.text:
Specify a custom retention period in hours for more aggressive cleanup.

fab table vacuum ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Tables/temp_processing_data --retain_n_hours 48

  1. Requires explicit enablement ↩↩

docs.title: Workspace Examples
docs.text:
This page demonstrates how to manage Microsoft Fabric workspaces using the CLI. Workspaces are containers for Fabric items and provide collaboration and security boundaries.

Resource Type

Type: .Workspace

To explore all workspace commands and their parameters, run:

fab desc .Workspace

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Navigate to a workspace using the full workspace path.

fab cd /ws1.Workspace

Navigate to a workspace using relative path from current context.

fab cd ../../ws1.Workspace

Navigate to your personal workspace using the workspace name or shortcut.

# Using workspace name
fab cd "My workspace.Personal"

# Using shortcut
fab cd ~

docs.title: Create Workspace
docs.text: Create a workspace. Use -P capacityName=<capacity name> to specify inline capacity (default: CLI-configured capacity config set default_capacity <>).

docs.title: Create with Default Capacity
docs.text:
Create a workspace using the CLI-configured default capacity.

fab create ws1.Workspace

docs.title: Create with Specific Capacity
docs.text:
Create a workspace and assign it to a specific capacity.

fab create ws1.Workspace -P capacityname=capac1

docs.title: Create Without Capacity
docs.text:
Create a workspace without assigning it to any capacity.

fab create ws1.Workspace -P capacityname=none

docs.title: Check Workspace Existence
docs.text:
Check if a workspace exists and is accessible.

fab exists ws1.Workspace

docs.title: Get Workspace Details
docs.text:
Retrieve full workspace details.

fab get ws1.Workspace

docs.title: Query Specific Properties
docs.text:
Query workspace properties using JMESPath syntax.

fab get ws1.Workspace -q id

docs.title: Export Query Results
docs.text:
Save query results to a local file.

fab get ws1.Workspace -q sparkSettings -o /tmp

docs.title: List All Workspaces and Folders
docs.text:
Display available workspaces with different detail levels.

# Simple list
fab ls

# Detailed list
fab ls -l

# Include hidden elements
fab ls -l -a

Hidden elements at tenant level include:

  • Capacities (.capacities)
  • Connections (.connections)
  • Domains (.domains)
  • Gateways (.gateways)

docs.title: List Workspace Items
docs.text:
Display items within a specific workspace.

# Simple list
fab ls ws1.Workspace

# Detailed list
fab ls ws1.Workspace -l

# Include hidden workspace elements
fab ls ws1.Workspace -la

Hidden elements at workspace level include:

  • External Data Shares (.ExternalDataShare)
  • Managed Identities (.ManagedIdentity)
  • Managed Private Endpoints (.ManagedPrivateEndpoint)
  • Spark Pools (.SparkPool)

To always show hidden elements without using -a, configure: fab config set show_hidden true

docs.title: Update Workspace Display Name
docs.text:
Change the workspace display name.

fab set ws1.Workspace -q displayName -i ws2r

docs.title: Update Workspace Description
docs.text:
Set or modify the workspace description.

fab set ws1.Workspace -q description -i "New description"

docs.title: Configure Spark Runtime Version
docs.text:
Update the Spark runtime version for the workspace.

fab set ws1.Workspace -q sparkSettings.environment.runtimeVersion -i 1.2

docs.title: Assign Starter Pool
docs.text:
Assign the Starter Pool as the default pool for the workspace.

fab set ws1.Workspace -q sparkSettings.pool.defaultPool -i '{"name": "Starter Pool","type": "Workspace"}'

docs.title: Assign Custom Pool
docs.text:
Assign a custom Spark pool as the default pool.

fab set ws1.Workspace -q sparkSettings.pool.defaultPool -i '{"name": "spool1","type": "Workspace","id": "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000"}'

docs.title: Remove Multiple Workspaces Interactively
docs.text:
Select and remove multiple workspaces (interactive mode only).

fab rm .

docs.title: Remove Workspace Items Selectively
docs.text:
Remove specific items from a workspace (interactive mode).

fab rm ws1.Workspace

docs.title: Force Remove Entire Workspace
docs.text:
Delete workspace and all its contents without confirmation.

fab rm ws1.Workspace -f

Using -f flag will delete the entire workspace and all items permanently. Use with extreme caution

docs.title: Export Workspace Items
docs.text:
When you export item definition, the sensitivity label is not part of the definition

Export items from a workspace to an output path. Supported for exportable items; use -a to export all the items.

docs.title: Export Workspace Items to Local Directory
docs.text:
Export items from a workspace to a local directory.

Windows OS File Name Restrictions

In Windows, items with names containing \ / : * ? " < > | will cause export errors. Provide a valid name in the output path to resolve this: 

fab export "ws1.Workspace/n?1.Notebook" -o "/tmp/n1.Notebook"


fab export ws1.Workspace -o /tmp

# Export all items
fab export ws1.Workspace -o /tmp -a

docs.title: Export Workspace Items to Lakehouse Files
docs.text:
Export workspace items directly to a Lakehouse Files location.

fab export ws1.Workspace -o /ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files

# Export all items
fab export ws1.Workspace -o /ws1.Workspace/lh1.Lakehouse/Files -a

docs.title: Copy Items Between Workspaces
docs.text:
Copy items from one workspace to another. Supported for exportable items.

fab cp ws1.Workspace ws2.Workspace

docs.title: Move Items Between Workspaces
docs.text:
Move items from one workspace to another (interactive mode only).

fab mv ws1.Workspace ws2.Workspace

docs.title: Open Workspace in Web Browser
docs.text:
Launch the workspace in your default web browser.

fab open ws1.Workspace
